conclusion: The working principle of the electromagnetic railgun is that the projectile to be launched can move freely between two parallel rails and maintain good contact with the rails. Current flows in from one rail, passes through the conductive projectile, and then flows back through the other rail. The rail current generates a magnetic field perpendicular to the plane of the rails at the projectile (which can be considered as a uniform magnetic field). The electrified projectile is then propelled at high speed along the rails due to the Lorentz force acting on it.

Xiao Ming purchased a railgun model online, with a rail length of $( L = 0.5 \mathrm{m} )$, a parallel rail spacing of $( d = 0.02 \mathrm{m} )$, a projectile mass of $( m = 0.02 \mathrm{kg} )$, a rail current of $( I = 10 \mathrm{A} )$, and a magnetic field strength of $( B = 1 \mathrm{T} )$. All resistances are neglected.

The image shows a schematic of an electromagnetic railgun. It includes two parallel rails with a projectile moving between them. The current flows from one rail, through the projectile, and back to the other rail, generating a magnetic field that propels the projectile.

premise: The electromagnetic railgun works by applying a current through the projectile, which generates a magnetic field. The Lorentz force acts on the projectile, propelling it forward.
conclusion: The force \( F \) on the projectile is given by the Lorentz force equation: \[ F = I \times B \times d \] where \( I \) is the current, \( B \) is the magnetic field strength, and \( d \) is the rail spacing.

premise: The acceleration \( a \) of the projectile is: \[ a = \frac{F}{m} = \frac{0.2 \, \text{N}}{0.02 \, \text{kg}} \]
Using the equation of motion: \[ v^2 = u^2 + 2as \] where \( u = 0 \) (initial velocity), \( a = 10 \, \text{m/s}^2 \), and \( s = 0.5 \, \text{m} \]
The power \( P \) is given by: \[ P = F \times v = 0.2 \, \text{N} \times \sqrt{10} \, \text{m/s} \]
Rounding to two decimal places: \[ P \approx 0.63 \, \text{W} \]
